page.title: 18Emborough Walls & Coppices
page.content: Dry stone walls and narrow lanes are a common sight in the Parish of Emborough and surrounding areas. Some are of Roman Origin and built of grey stone quarried in the area. ay walls have now sunk beneath natural hedges of thorn and hazel etc. and become stone banks. These form good shelter for farm animals, wildlife and birds, as do the numerous woods and coppice which are mostly of deciduous trees like the ash, Scycamore, Oak and ech. Empty spaces are visible here and there where the elm once stood in the days before Dutch Elm Disease. The small circular coppices which are seen in the larger walled fields were planted as wind breaks to shelter outlying cattle during the winter months.
